claim.text: The Multimodal Deep Regression Model (MDRM) significantly outperforms other benchmark methods in predicting stock volatility using earnings conference call data.
claim.exact_quote: The results show that our multimodal deep regression model (MDRM) outperforms all baselines.

evidence.evidence_text: Using both text and audio data, MDRM achieved a lower prediction error across all tested durations compared to unimodal and other benchmark methods.
evidence.limitations: Limitations include potential overfitting with audio data and diminishing returns for long-term predictions.
evidence.exact_quote: Using both text and audio data, the model has prediction error of 1.371, 0.420, 0.300 and 0.217 for 3-days, 7-days, 15-days and 30-days following the conference call respectively.

evidence.evidence_text: MDRM's performance showcases a substantial improvement over simple fusion methods and traditional unimodal analyses, indicating the effectiveness of integrating verbal and vocal cues.
evidence.limitations: Specific comparative metrics for long-term prediction reliability and potential model overfitting are not discussed in depth.
evidence.exact_quote: It is worth emphasizing the substantial improvement over simple fusion model.

evaluation.justification: The claim is strongly supported by empirical evidence presenting quantitative improvements in stock volatility predictions, showcasing the MDRM's performance superiority.
evaluation.key_limitations: Potential overfitting with audio-only data and less significance of results for long-term predictions.

claim.text: Both verbal and vocal modalities contribute to the improved accuracy of stock volatility predictions.
claim.exact_quote: We can also conclude from the results that multimodal features are more helpful than unimodal features (either text or audio) alone.

evidence.evidence_text: The multimodal approach (combining text and audio) outperforms either unimodal approach alone, illustrating the value of integrating both types of data.
evidence.limitations: The comparisons are quantitative but do not extensively discuss the qualitative aspects of how these modalities interact.
evidence.exact_quote: When we predict the stock volatility 3-days following the conference call, multimodal (1.371) outperform unimodal (1.431) by 4.2%.

evaluation.justification: The evidence clearly supports the claim that leveraging both verbal and vocal data modalities enhances prediction accuracy, though deeper insight into their interaction could strengthen the finding.
evaluation.key_limitations: Lack of qualitative analysis on the interaction of modalities.
